DOC.HEAD: Program Slated for King High is Canceled
DOC.TEXT: Bowing to opposition led by the widow of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., the Board of Education has reversed itself and decided to keep ROTC out of the high school named for the late civil rights leader. The board voted to cancel the three-year program of the Air Force Junior Reserve Officers Training Corps that was to have begun in February, Robert F. Wagner Jr., board president, said Thursday. The board had approved the program in June, two months after the faculty voted 102-59 against it. Wagner said a letter from Mrs. King to the board on Nov. 15 was decisive. It said: ``My late husband, Dr. King, believed in the principles of non-violence and worked tirelessly to pass this message on to the youth of America. While I understand the need for ROTC programs in other high schools, I believe that a military program has no place in a school named in his honor.'' Three city high schools have ROTC programs, which afford students who complete the course a chance for scholarships and possible admission to service academies. Air Force officials have said that if the program scheduled for King High were not instituted there, it would be moved to another city, possibly Rochester.
